articles.headline: Religious Groups Given ‘Exception’ to Work Bias Law
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court found a “ministerial exception” to job discrimination laws, saying religious groups must be free to choose leaders without government interference.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court found a “ministerial exception” to job discrimination laws, saying religious groups must be free to choose leaders without government interference.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In what may be its most significant religious liberty decision in two decades, the Supreme Court on Wednesday for the first time recognized a “ministerial exception” to employment discrimination laws, saying that churches and other religious groups must be free to choose and dismiss their leaders without government interference.

articles.headline: If You’re Mad for ‘Downton,’ Publishers Have Reading List
articles.snippet: The popularity of all things “Downton Abbey” has American book marketers trying to ride a British aristocracy wave.
articles.abstract: The popularity of all things “Downton Abbey” has American book marketers trying to ride a British aristocracy wave.
articles.lead_paragraph: The British melodrama “Downton Abbey” is already the darling of American public television. Now it has become a marketing tool for booksellers and publishers hoping to tap into the passion of the show’s audience.

articles.headline: Adversaries of Iran Said to Be Stepping Up Covert Actions
articles.snippet: A campaign of bombings, assassinations, defections and cyberattacks, which experts believe is mainly Israel’s work, seems meant to halt Iran’s progress toward a nuclear weapon.
articles.abstract: A campaign of bombings, assassinations, defections and cyberattacks, which experts believe is mainly Israel’s work, seems meant to halt Iran’s progress toward a nuclear weapon.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As arguments flare in Israel and the United States about a possible military strike to set back Iran’s nuclear program, an accelerating covert campaign of assassinations, bombings, cyberattacks and defections appears intended to make that debate irrelevant, according to current and former American officials and specialists on Iran.

articles.headline: Sampling the Future of Gadgetry
articles.snippet: The Consumer Electronics Show displays a future of proliferating gadgetry, from the serious to the frivolous.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Electronics Show displays a future of proliferating gadgetry, from the serious to the frivolous.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — If you just peek into the huge International Consumer Electronics Show, you might think that it’s mostly a deafening showcase for tablets, thin TV screens, superthin laptops and Android phones.

articles.headline: Against Odds, Path Opens Up for U.S.-Taliban Talks
articles.snippet: The Taliban’s willingness to open a political office in Qatar represents a critical point in the United States’s attempt to negotiate an end to the war in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The Taliban’s willingness to open a political office in Qatar represents a critical point in the United States’s attempt to negotiate an end to the war in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the last year, Marc Grossman, a veteran but low-key diplomat, led a small team of American officials who met secretly from Doha, Qatar, to Munich with a shadowy representative of Afghanistan’s Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar, in hopes of starting peace talks.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers, Matthew Rosenberg and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A Blend of Politics and Pragmatism at the Auto Show
articles.snippet: Politicians hoping to secure factory jobs for their states were among the visitors at the Detroit auto show’s preview week.
articles.abstract: Politicians hoping to secure factory jobs for their states were among the visitors at the Detroit auto show’s preview week.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — As the automotive industry rebounds, this year’s Detroit auto show features more dazzle, more optimism and more politicians winding their way through the exhibits.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Turning to Tech on the Road
articles.snippet: As cars become ever more vibrant entertainment centers, automakers find themselves having to build safety features to prevent drivers from crashing their smartphone on wheels.
articles.abstract: As cars become ever more vibrant entertainment centers, automakers find themselves having to build safety features to prevent drivers from crashing their smartphone on wheels.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — If Mercedes, BMW and Ford have their way, the new cars they build will be able to port apps, games, music and movies from a smartphone to a car’s entertainment system.

articles.headline: Europe Gets Some Reassurance in Auctions of Debt
articles.snippet: Solid government bond sales in Italy and Spain indicated that efforts by the European Central Bank to avoid a regional credit freeze were still showing at least short-term benefits.
articles.abstract: Solid government bond sales in Italy and Spain indicated that efforts by the European Central Bank to avoid a regional credit freeze were still showing at least short-term benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Solid government debt auctions in Italy and Spain on Thursday indicated that efforts by the European Central Bank to avoid a regional credit freeze were continuing to show at least short-term benefits.
